citeinfo.origin: New York State Department of Health, Bureau of Water Supply Protection
citeinfo.title: Public Water Supply 2021

descript.abstract: Drinking Water Treatment Plant means any plant or equipment which, through the addition of chemicals or through aeration, ion exchange, demineralization, coagulation, sedimentation or filtration, or through any other means or combinations of treatment, shall change the physical, chemical, radiological or microbiological quality of water. A critical infrastructure data set, subject to data distribution limitations. Point Coverage representing locations of public water supply Treatment Plants and associated water system data. Last updated 3/8/21
descript.purpose: Provide accurate locations of Drinking Water facilities for emergency preparedness and security planning in GIS format.

timeperd.current: Information entered by county and state public health officials at various times.

place.placekey: New York State, Water Treatment Plants, Intakes, Wells, Springs, water, drinking, Albany County, Allegany County, Bronx County, Broome County, Cattaraugus County, Cayuga County, Chautauqua County, Chemung County, Chenango County, Clinton County, Columbia County, Cortland County, Delaware County, Dutchess County, Erie County, Essex County, Franklin County, Fulton County, Genesee County, Greene County, Hamilton County, Herkimer County, Jefferson County, Kings County, Lewis County, Livingston County, Madison County, Monroe County, Montgomery County, Nassau County, New York County, Niagara County, Oneida County, Onondaga County, Ontario County, Orange County, Orleans County, Oswego County, Otsego County, Putnam County, Queens County, Rensselaer County, Richmond County, Rockland County, Saratoga County, Schenectady County, Schoharie County, Schuyler County, Seneca County, St Lawrence County, Steuben County, Suffolk County, Sullivan County, Tioga County, Tompkins County, Ulster County, Warren County, Washington County, Wayne County, Westchester County, Wyoming County, Yates County

idinfo.accconst: Purpose is for emergency preparedness and security - access is limited to appropriate Department personnel and emergency response personnel. No redistribution is permitted, including under FOIL.
idinfo.useconst: Not for re-distribution, subset redistribution, or static redistribution

detailed.attrdef: The state and county unique public water system identifier. Systems are comprised of facilities.

overview.eaover:
Digital data is tested by visual comparison with intake location mapping, digital orthophotography, ALIS data sets, DOT planimetric maps, and USGS Quads . This GIS coverage contains all intakes with available coordinates for public water systems as defined by the State Sanitary Code, Subpart 5-1, and entered into the Safe Drinking Water Information Systems (SDWIS) database. Accuracy depends on method of collection.
>Number of data records: 417 >Field Name Type Width Desc >1 Water_System_Name Character 40 0 >2 Water_SystemID Character 12 0 >3 Source_Name Character 40 0 >4 Source_Type Character 2 0 >5 Principal_County_Served Character 19 0 >6 FacilityID Integer 11 0 >7 Water_System_Type Character 4 0 >8 Additional_Reg_Agency Character 72 0 >9 Contact_Name Character 50 0 >10 Contact_Phone_Number Character 24 0 >11 Population_Served Integer 11 0
overview.eadetcit: Water Treatment Plants were extracted from the Safe Drinking Water Information System Oracle files into a Microsoft Access Database, and imported to ArcGIS 10 table file. From the table file, points were created based upon the Latitude Longitude (NAD 83) fields within SDWIS. A locational accuracy was implemented using the following criteria: intake must fall within the bounds of New York State; intake must fall within the county assigned to that intake (and verified if outside); intake must fall within water or be directly adjacent. All intakes which did not meet any of the above criteria were further checked against the New York State's Digital Orthophotography, and then corrected based on available GIS information or returned to their respective local health office for location verification and correction. A final check was made of the location of all water system intakes for correction and completion of the data quality control. Data was re-projected to UTM NAD 83 Zone 18. An additional field was added to the data set to describe cases where an additional regulatory responsibility other than the State Health or local health departments exist.

Wells were extracted from the Safe Drinking Water Information System Oracle files into a Microsoft Access Database, and imported to ArcGIS 10 table file. From the table file, points were created based upon the Latitude Longitude (NAD 83) fields within SDWIS. A locational accuracy was implemented using the following criteria: intake must fall within the bounds of New York State; intake must fall within the county assigned to that intake (and verified if outside); intake must fall within water or be directly adjacent. All Wells which did not meet any of the above criteria were further checked against the New York State's Digital Orthophotography, and then corrected based on available GIS information or returned to their respective local health office for location verification and correction. A final check was made of the location of all water system Wells for correction and completion of the data quality control. Data was re-projected to UTM NAD 83 Zone 18. An additional field was added to the data set to describe cases where an additional regulatory responsibility other than the State Health or local health departments exist.

Intakes were extracted from the Safe Drinking Water Information System Oracle files into a Microsoft Access Database, and imported to ArcGIS 10 table file. From the table file, points were created based upon the Latitude Longitude (NAD 83) fields within SDWIS. A locational accuracy was implemented using the following criteria: intake must fall within the bounds of New York State; intake must fall within the county assigned to that intake (and verified if outside); intake must fall within water or be directly adjacent. All intakes which did not meet any of the above criteria were further checked against the New York State's Digital Orthophotography, and then corrected based on available GIS information or returned to their respective local health office for location verification and correction. A final check was made of the location of all water system intakes for correction and completion of the data quality control. Data was re-projected to UTM NAD 83 Zone 18. An additional field was added to the data set to describe cases where an additional regulatory responsibility other than the State Health or local health departments exist.

Springs were extracted from the Safe Drinking Water Information System Oracle files into a Microsoft Access Database, and imported to ArcGIS 10 table file. From the table file, points were created based upon the Latitude Longitude (NAD 83) fields within SDWIS. A locational accuracy was implemented using the following criteria: intake must fall within the bounds of New York State; intake must fall within the county assigned to that intake (and verified if outside); intake must fall within water or be directly adjacent. All intakes which did not meet any of the above criteria were further checked against the New York State's Digital Orthophotography, and then corrected based on available GIS information or returned to their respective local health office for location verification and correction. A final check was made of the location of all water system intakes for correction and completion of the data quality control. Data was re-projected to UTM NAD 83 Zone 18. An additional field was added to the data set to describe cases where an additional regulatory responsibility other than the State Health or local health departments exist.

Infiltration Galleries were extracted from the Safe Drinking Water Information System Oracle files into a Microsoft Access Database, and imported to ArcGIS 10 table file. From the table file, points were created based upon the Latitude Longitude (NAD 83) fields within SDWIS. A locational accuracy was implemented using the following criteria: Infiltration Galleries must fall within the bounds of New York State; Infiltration Galleries must fall within the county assigned to that Infiltration Galleries (and verified if outside); Infiltration Galleries must fall within water or be directly adjacent. All Infiltration Galleries which did not meet any of the above criteria were further checked against the New York State's Digital Orthophotography, and then corrected based on available GIS information or returned to their respective local health office for location verification and correction. A final check was made of the location of all water system Infiltration Galleries for correction and completion of the data quality control. Data was re-projected to UTM NAD 83 Zone 18. An additional field was added to the data set to describe cases where an additional regulatory responsibility other than the State Health or local health departments exist.

dataIdInfo.idPurp: Provide accurate locations of Drinking Water facilities for emergency preparedness and security planning in GIS format.
dataIdInfo.idAbs: Drinking Water Treatment Plant means any plant or equipment which, through the addition of chemicals or through aeration, ion exchange, demineralization, coagulation, sedimentation or filtration, or through any other means or combinations of treatment, shall change the physical, chemical, radiological or microbiological quality of water. A critical infrastructure data set, subject to data distribution limitations. Point Coverage representing locations of public water supply Treatment Plants and associated water system data. Last updated 3/8/21
